lenses.name: Asahi Optical Co. Super-Multi-Coated Takumar 85mm f/1.8-16
Asahi Optical Co. Super-Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16 (v1) 8 elements
lenses.description:
The first version of Super-Takumar 50/1.4 with 8 elements optical design.
Introduced with the original Spotmatic. Can't be used on earlier bodies due to the protruding rear element (earlier bodies could be modified by changing the original square aperture actuator to the curved type). 
The earlier version can be recognized by the IR mark being inside "4" and the protruding rear element. Later 7 element version of the lens has IR mark between "8" and "4".
The protruding rear element of the earlier version extends outside its metal holder (about 0.5 mm and due to curvature even more).
The newer, 1966-1971 versions, has its rear element entirely inside the metal casing, though both lenses extend the rear noticeably outside the body when focused to infinity.
Takumar 50/1.4 versions:
Asahi Optical Co. Super-Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16 (v1) 8 elements (this page)
Asahi Optical Co. Super-Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16 (v2) 7 elements
Asahi Optical Co. Super-Multi-Coated-Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16
Asahi Optical Co. SMC Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16

There are 2 versions of Super-Takumar 135/3.5 - first was made in 1963-1965 and has 5 elements / 4 groups optical design, same as Auto-Takumar 135/3.5 and Takumar 135/3.5 v2.
Second version was made in 1965-1971 with 4 elements / 4 groups design.
For Takumar 135/3.5 versions list check Asahi Optical Co. Takumar 135mm f/3.5-22 (v1) page.

lenses.name: Asahi Optical Co. Super-Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16 (v2) 7 elements
lenses.description:
The second version of Super-Takumar 50/1.4 with 7 elements optical design.
Lens can be identified from its predecessor by observing
where the "IR" mark is. If it is inside "4", it is the original 8 element design if it is outside "4", it is the later 7 element design.
The later design was not modified other than SMC coatings up
through the SMC Pentax 50mm f1.4.
The use of a rare earth element in the rear groups cause
yellowing over time in the later versions. This yellowing can be bleached out by exposing the elements to UV in the form of sunlight or UV lamp for weeks.
One week under 11W UV tube removes about 70% of the coloration, one month roughly 95%.
For the full list of Takumar 50/1.4 versions and more info visit Asahi Optical Co. Super-Takumar 50mm f/1.4-16 (v1) page.

lenses.name: Belomo MS Peleng 3.5/8A Fisheye 8mm f/3.5-16
lenses.description:
This is the famous "Russian"
circular fisheye, although the usable field of view is more like
160 degrees versus 180. On a full frame dSLR or on fillm, the image
circle created by the lens has a diameter larger than 24mm, so
there is some cropping of the picture. In the case of 1.6 crop
dSLRs, there remains some of the black circle edge in the pictures,
although it is limited to the far corners. Fisheye distortion is
still strong in the case of the 1.6 crop however.

The lens has an interchangeable mount and comes with a set of
filters that screw onto the rear element. The rear element also
protrudes rather far from the lens into the camera body, so in some
cases there lies the possibility of damage to the mirror. It would
be wise to check the compatibility of your camera with this. Some
remove the rearmost element; this usually solves the problem,
however the lens loses infinity focus.

At some point Belomo dropped 'Peleng' from the lens name,
lenses from later batches are named 'Belomo EWP Fisheye Lens MC
3.5/8 A'.

The later version (starting with MC Pancolar M42 mount and used in PB mount version also) has a redesigned configuration of 6 elements in 5 groups with modification done to front and rear negative elements. Rear pair was splitted into independent groups.

lenses.name: Carl Zeiss Jena Triotar T 13.5cm f/4-22
lenses.description:
This version has heavy
stainless steel body. Triotar is basically the same lens as used
pre-war and remounted from a medium Format standard lens. Thus its
most characteristic aspect is the long tube mount with the lens
placed well forward. It was supposed to be the economical
alternative to 135mm Sonnar. Were initially made in a heavy slim
barrel with manual aperture and later light alloy pre-set mount.
There were versions with aperture stopping down to f/16, later
f/22. and a few going to f/45 (The same basic lens head as used in
Exakta for macro work, the 45 is for DOF). 
f/45 versions were made for use with the Ihagee Exakta
Kolpofot, a very strong ring flash for medical use. 

The later version is 

here.

lenses.name: Dr.Weth Berlin Telestigmar 175-315mm f/3.5(6.3)-45
lenses.description:
An unique lens made by Dr.
Weth, a retired engineer. Telestigmar lens consists of several
parts used in various combinations to achieve diferrent focal
lengths. 
The main parts are: 
1. Basic prime lens (250mm f/5 , 2 elements in 1 group) with
aperture and focusing assembly. 
2. Tube "N" with negative supplementary lens. 
3. Tube "P" with positive supplementary lens. 
4. Tube "Z" - spacer tube. 
 Tube combinations: 
P + Basic Lens: 175mm f/3.5-22 
N + P + Basic Lens: 225mm f/4.5-32 
Z + Basic Lens: 250mm f/5-32 
N + Z + Basic Lens: 315mm f/6.3-45 

Close focusing extender tube and various mounts adapters were
available from Dr. Weth 
First lenses were made with M42 mount adapter, later also
Exakta and Alpa. 

You can read very interesting article about this lens 
here - 
"The Magical Optic of Dr. Weth" by Peter
Dechert.

M42 Zenit. Both lens types have preset diaphragm. 
The Helios-44 line (many versions from KMZ, BeLOMO, and
Lytkarino) came out with each Zenit camera model introduced. Lens
design was copied from the Carl Zeiss Biotar. First version of
Helios-44 even looked similar to Carl Zeiss Biotar, both had
'silver' aluminium barrel finish and M39 mount, all specs were the
same.

lenses.name: Mamiya Auto Mamiya/Sekor SX 21mm f/4-16
lenses.description:
A multicoated lens to
accomodate the latests M42 bodies produced by Mamiya. This ultra
wide angle performs rather well in many ways: distortion is quite
low, resolution remains good at the corners, and the lens is not
too prone to flare. This particular lens has warm tones and
saturates greens. 
The SX series allow open aperture metering on Mamiya bodies
only, and the pin that transmits the aperture information to the
body could prevent mounting the lens on adapers, unless it is
removed. Also worth mentionning is the absence of an auto/manual
diaphragm switch. This again will cause problems when the lens is
mounted with an adapter. Works well on spotmatics, though.

lenses.name: Mamiya Macro Sekor 60mm f/2.8-22
lenses.description:
Lens body length is 66mm at
infinity and 130mm fully extended at 1:1.
Early version has bright 'silver' filter thread finish.

lenses.name: Meyer-Optik Gorlitz Oreston 50mm f/1.8-22
lenses.description:
Oreston / Pentacon 50/1.8 was
first manufactured for the Exakta RTL-1000 in auto mount, and later
in M42, M42 Electric, and later (until the late 80's) in Praktica B
mount.
This lens has several interesting features, it can focus right
down to 33 cm , good enough for most close up; lesser known is the
fact that the lens has almost perfect symmetrical design very
similar to the original Zeiss double Gauss Planar design (with
thick cemented center groups) making it a very usable lens for
reverse mount and bellows work. In fact it was remarked by many
experienced in this lens that it performs excellently in the macro / close up range.

lenses.description: A triplet design with only three elements. Definition at the corners on a full frame camera is so-so at open aperture, OK at f/5.6, very good at f/8, and better at f/11 and 16.

Meyer-Optik Gorlitz Primoplan 58mm f/1.9-22 (v2)
lenses.description:
The Primoplan is actually a modernized and coated version of the same named lens designed and introduced pre-war. None the less, this lens enjoy quite famed reputation as being eccentric in its optical design (a radically modified triplet) and its performance, being hailed as "amazing" at its time of introduction. All M42 Primoplan are manufactured in light alloy mount. most are in pre-set version but there do exist a very are and early variation with manual diaphram and much smaller filter mount (probably 32mm).

Versions:
Meyer-Optik Gorlitz Primoplan 58mm f/1.9-22 (v1)
Meyer-Optik Gorlitz Primoplan 58mm f/1.9-22 (v2)

lenses.name: Mir-1B 37mm f/2.8-16
lenses.description:
Current version of Mir-1 lens is known as "Mir-1V" (or "Mir-1B" in deference to the original cyrillic marking).
The optical formula on either lens appears to be the same as the original Mir-1.  There may be some coating quality differences, and of course, the most obvious difference is the lens mount. 

The lens is still made today by KMZ in Russia.  When buying this lens, make sure it says "MIR-1B" or MIR-1V" if you're planning to use it in an M42 camera.  Many Mir-1 are the older Zenit M-39 mount and will not fit to M42 mount without proper adapter.

The lens requires a good hood when shooting into the sun.  The 37mm focal length may seem a bit odd, but its field is comparable to a 35mm lens.  In fact many 35mm lenses have real focal lengths which are longer than marked.  The Mir-1V just happens to be candid and honest about it.

There are two versions of this
Cosina made lens. They are identical optically but there are some
differences in mechanical part, especially for infinity focus
adjustment. Earlier version with metal focusing ring 

(v4a)has adjustable focusing ring stopper plate. Rubber grip
version 

(v4b)has no ability to adjust infinity, there is a metal spacer
ring between optical assembly and helicoid assembly and the only
way to adjust infinity is to change spacer thickness. 

This lens also known as:
Cosina Cosinon Auto 55mm f/1.4-16 (v1)
Carenar Super Carenar 55mm f/1.4-16
Vivitar VMC Auto 55mm f/1.4-16

lenses.name: Schneider-Kreuznach C-Curtagon 35mm f/2.8-22
lenses.description:
This lens is one of the smallest and lightest M42 lenses. It measures just 55mm in height (with rubber hood - barely 32mm without!) and just 45mm in diameter, 146mm in circumference. Very sharp at all apertures, but has quite a long minimum focus distance (about 100cm) which means it is NOT very suitable for macro work. The hood easily slides off, but is solid once put on.
Do NOT confuse this with the other Curtagon 35mm 2.8 lens available, which is much older, larger and heavier.
This is the C-Curtagon, or 'baby C'.

lenses.name: Soligor Telephoto 135mm f/2.8-22 (early type)
lenses.description:
Very early Soligor lens made by Komura (Sankyo Kohki Komura) (Soligor was a brand of Allied Impex of New York).
Dates from 1956-1959, most likely. This was one of the pioneering products of the Japanese third party lens industry, along with those of Arco, Zunow, Sun, Kyoei and Fujita. Earliest reference to this type I have found was in Seymours Exakta catalog of 1956. Usually found in importers brands such as Soligor, Juplen, Peerotar and Spectra Coligon, and only rarely as a Komura. 
These are quite scarce in M42, more typical to find them in Exakta mount.

Min. focusing distance is 150cm in normal mode and 41cm in close focus mode.

lenses.name: Vivitar Series 1 Solid Catadioptric 600mm f/8
lenses.description: This is the first of Vivitar's solid catadioptric (lens-and-mirror) extreme telephotos. It is extremely compact (84mm long) and its optical elements - refractive glass and silver-coated mirrors - form almost a solid single element, making the lens virtually shock-proof and eliminating the central "hot spot" found in many such lenses. The lens mounts on the camera by means of T-adapter and has a rotating tripod socket. Number of elements: 9. Angle of view: 4°. Focuses to 7m (23ft). "Stops down" to equivalent of f/16 by means of a neutral density filter. Filter size: 35.5mm (rear mount).

lenses.name: Yashica Yashinon-DX 21mm f/3.3-16
lenses.description:
Rare and unique lens. This
lens is not retrofocal design, the rear element goes extremely deep
into the mirror box, camera mirror should be flipped up to mount
this lens. Can be used only on cameras with mirror lockup function
or mirrorless cameras.Originally comes with accessory shoe mounted
viewfinder (camera viewfinder can't be used with this lens because
of mirror lockup).
